DOCNAME: CASE OF VONTAS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of P1-1;Pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are the owners of a house and a surrounding plot of land with a surface area of QUANTITY , located on the island of GPE . The plot is adjacent to the promenade of LOC . The title deeds relating to this property , duly deposited in ORG , date back to DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP In particular , on DATE ORG bought the plot at a public auction conducted by ORG . On DATE ORG sold the plot to GPE , who sold it to her daughter PERSON on DATE . The latter donated a part of the plot to her daughter , the third applicant , on DATE . On DATE CARDINAL F.V. donated the remaining part of the plot to her son , the first applicant . On DATE the first applicant granted himself a life interest in the property and settled the remainder on his daughter , the second applicant .

CARDINAL . All these transactions were executed by deeds of public notaries duly deposited in the transcription registry . The applicants have always declared the property to be in their ownership and have paid the relevant taxes on it .
CARDINAL . In DATE the first applicant applied to ORG of the municipality of PERSON for a permit to start minor building works .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the municipality of PERSON claimed that the northern part of the land in question constituted land for public use . On DATE ORG rejected the first applicant ’s request on the ground that the topographical survey submitted by the applicants was inaccurate , as it wrongly included public land among their property .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the municipality of PERSON and the applicants filed opposing claims with ORG , each asking to be declared the owners of the disputed piece of land .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG delivered an interlocutory judgment ordering a number of expert assessments . In particular , the court appointed ORG , a civil engineer , to conduct an expert assessment in order to clarify whether the disputed land was included in the ORG title deeds ( decision no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG took into consideration the ORG title deeds , the planning legislation in force and the official topographical and planning charts of ORG of the Piraeus Prefecture and produced his expert report . After having prepared a topographical survey , he concluded that the disputed land was included in the ORG title deeds .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG Instance dismissed the applicants’ claims , holding that an area of QUANTITY on the northern side of the applicants’ garden constituted public land ( judgment no . CARDINAL ) . In particular , ORG took into account several witnesses’ testimonies and aerial photographs and attached particular importance to the fact that the applicants had never exercised any ownership rights over that part of the land , since they had never cultivated it or planted trees or erected a fence there .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicants’ appeal ( judgment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . In particular , it held that according to a rule of NORP - Roman law ( vetustas ) , which had been applied in GPE before the introduction of LAW in DATE , a property could be considered to be “ for public use ” ( κοινόχρηστο ) if it had been in common use for “ an indefinite number of DATE in human memory ” ( αμνημονεύτου χρόνου αρχαιότητα ) . It further explained that , for this rule to be applied , CARDINAL generations of people , each CARDINAL spanning DATE had to remember that the disputed land had been in public use in the past . This DATE period in human memory must had to have been completed by DATE , the date on which LAW had come into force , since the LAW did not provide for such a rule .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , ORG applied the above rule and found that it was proved from the testimonies of the witnesses put forward by the municipality of PERSON that the disputed land had been freely used by local people DATE and had thus become public . It concluded that , independently of the question whether the disputed land was included in the ORG title deeds , it had become land “ for public use ” , and thus part of the municipality ’s property . Furthermore , it considered that the fact that the land in issue did not appear as public property in the official planning charts of the island of GPE was of no importance since the land had become public because of its public use .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal . It held that ORG had correctly applied NORP - Roman law to the facts of the case . It accepted that it had been proved that the disputed land had been in common use since DATE and concluded that the applicants had never become its owners ( judgment no . CARDINAL ) . Its judgment was “ finalised ” ( καθαρoγραφή ) on DATE .
